[{'type': 'delete', 'from': 'a', 'str': 'a deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā', 'to': 'ā̊', 'str': 'ā̊ for ā', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a well-documented orthographic feature in Iranian manuscripts, reflecting a tendency for the letter ā̊ to disappear by evolving into ā. This change is particularly prevalent in later Iranian copies from the 19th century, where ā replaces ā̊ in a high percentage of occurrences (over 75% in some manuscripts). Possible reasons suggested include Indian influence or erroneous transcription. In contrast, Indian manuscripts exhibit different behaviours for ā̊, such as its use for āu or its graphical representation as ā/ə in line-breaks, implying a pronunciation similar to /āo/ or /āe/'}]

This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ai', 'to': 'a', 'str': 'a for ai', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'the diphthong aē frequently monophthongizes to ai in Indian manuscripts'}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ii', 'to': 'ai', 'str': 'ai for ii', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'i', 'str': 'i deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā', 'to': 'ā̊', 'str': 'ā̊ for ā', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a well-documented orthographic feature in Iranian manuscripts, reflecting a tendency for the letter ā̊ to disappear by evolving into ā. This change is particularly prevalent in later Iranian copies from the 19th century, where ā replaces ā̊ in a high percentage of occurrences (over 75% in some manuscripts). Possible reasons suggested include Indian influence or erroneous transcription. In contrast, Indian manuscripts exhibit different behaviours for ā̊, such as its use for āu or its graphical representation as ā/ə in line-breaks, implying a pronunciation similar to /āo/ or /āe/'}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ϑ', 'to': 's', 'str': 's for ϑ', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In the Behdini recitation (Iranian tradition), the fricative ϑ is described as 'very infrequent' and often functions as a 'defective pronunciation' of s. This implies a phonological shift where s can be realised as ϑ. In Persian transcriptions of Avestan, ϑ is sometimes represented as s, particularly within the consonant cluster ϑr (e.g., srūštā for ϑraōštā). [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'aō', 'to': 'ōi', 'str': 'ōi for aō', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'aō for ō are also frequent in Iranian manuscripts, especially during the Zand period'}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). Possible reasons suggested include Indian influence or erroneous transcription. [{'type': 'insert', 'to': 'a', 'str': 'a inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'ϑ', 'str': 'ϑ inserted', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'ā', 'str': 'ā inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This refers to anaptyxis (vowel insertion). [{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā', 'to': 'ā̊', 'str': 'ā̊ for ā', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a well-documented orthographic feature in Iranian manuscripts, reflecting a tendency for the letter ā̊ to disappear by evolving into ā. Possible reasons suggested include Indian influence or erroneous transcription. [{'type': 'insert', 'to': 'c', 'str': 'c inserted', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 'i', 'str': 'i inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}, {'type': 'insert', 'to': 't̰', 'str': 't̰ inserted', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}]

[{'type': 'insert', 'to': 'a', 'str': 'a inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'aē', 'to': 'ū', 'str': 'ū for aē', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'i', 'str': 'i deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. [{'type': 'insert', 'to': 'ə', 'str': 'ə inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]
